text: AMARA WALKER: Alex, what do

ALEXANDRA FIELD:
Look, they're being

closely watched and closely
monitored by this group
in the US, 38 North.

And this group says
that this shows

that activity has
resumed at the country's
main nuclear facility.

What they are looking at in
that image that has raised

the most concern is a
water plume coming off
of the cooling water outlet.

That is a distinct sign they
say that shows that the reactor

there is operational, though
they can't glean to what

extent, what power, what
strength that reactor
could be operational at.

But this is a
clear step forward,

if you compare it to
previous satellite images

that 38 North had released
earlier this month.

Those images suggested to
the analyst at 38 North

that preparations were being
made to make that reactor
operational once again.

At the time, we were
seeing images of snow

that had melted on the rooftop
of some of the buildings,

indicating that those
buildings were being occupied

for the first time in
some time, and that there
was minimal heat at least.

So these latest images showing
that water plume are certainly

a step forward, and this does
raise concern, it does continue

to raise awareness really for
the global community in face

of the fact that Kim Jong Un
announced back on New Year's

Day that the country was
getting ready to test

an intercontinental ballistic
missile, which he said

would have the
capability of reaching
the continental United States.

The activity that's being
observed by 30 North

here is at again the
main nuclear facility
in North Korea.

It's the place where,
and was believed,

that the plutonium
was made that has

been used in previous
nuclear tests, Amara.

AMARA WALKER: So we're seeing
this increased activity

as President Trump has been in
office for a couple weeks now.

Tell us about-- and are
there any indications

as to how North
Korea plans to deal
with President Donald Trump?

ALEXANDRA FIELD:
It's interesting.

It's the question
on everyone's mind,

of course, because you had Kim
Jong Un coming out and making

that statement that the
country was getting ready to do
that test on New Year's Day.
That's when he mentioned it.

No clear timeline on when
that test could happen,
but there are sources in both--

in the US and also in South
Korea who have indicated

that they feel that, you
know, those tests, you know,

could be very well prepared
for the next couple weeks,
from the next couple of months.

That this is something that
Donald Trump could face

early on in his
administration, an early test
of this administration.

At the time of Kim
Jong Un's announcement

that this test
was being readied,

Donald Trump responded,
President Trump responded

by tweeting it won't
happen, basically saying

that North Korea
wouldn't be allowed
to do something like this.

It is not clear yet what
Kim Jong Un's move will be,

when he could be ready
to launch this test.

But what you do have
coming up is the fact

that the Secretary of
Defense, Secretary Mattis,

is making his first
trip overseas to South
Korea and Japan this week.

That is meant to reassure allies
of the commitment of the US

to their longstanding
alliances here at a time when

those alliances have been
questioned by President

Trump, who was vocal
on the campaign trail,

raising concerns about
the level of spending

that the US was doing on
defense in South Korea.

So this is certainly a
tenuous situation right now.

Concerns in South Korea about
the possibility of a test,

and they want firm
assurances from the US

that they've got a stable
and reliable partner.

So everyone will be watching
this trip from the Secretary

of Defense later this week to
see what kind of reassurances

he's able to offer his
allies here in South Korea.
